document.docAuthor: Magalhães, Wagner F. & Bailey-Brock, Julie H.
document.masterDocTitle: Capitellidae Grube, 1862 (Annelida: Polychaeta) from the Hawaiian Islands with description of two new species

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Capitellidae Grube, 1862 (Annelida: Polychaeta) from the Hawaiian Islands with description of two new species

bibRefCitation.author: Langerhans
bibRefCitation.refString: Langerhans, P. (1881) Die Wurmfauna von Madeira. III. Zeitschrift fur wissenschaftliche Zoologie, 34 (1), 87 - 143.

paragraph.treatmentCitationGroup:
Capitella minima
.—
Green 2002
: 261
–263, fig. 4 a–f.
Capitomastus minimus .—
Eisig 1887
: 857
–859.
Capitella minimus
.-
Warren 1991
: 280
.

subSubSection.paragraph: Description. Complete specimens 2–7 mm long, 0.1–0.15 mm wide for about 28–45 chaetigers. Body elongate, wider on mid-thoracic chaetigers, gradually narrowing posteriorly; ventral groove beginning after chaetiger 6–7 ; groove deeper on abdominal segments. Color in alcohol white to pale yellow.

Prostomium triangular, rounded anteriorly, shorter or subequal in length to peristomium (
Figs 7
A–D, 8 A, C); nuchal organs and eyespots not observed. Peristomium distinct from prostomium forming complete ring; dorsally elevated and twice longer dorsally than ventrally (
Figs 7
A, 8 C). Proboscis not observed.

Thorax with nine chaetigers. Chaetal arrangement of thoracic chaetigers consistent throughout size range analyzed. Chaetigers 1–4 with four unilimbate capillaries per fascicle (
Fig. 8
D); chaetigers 5–7 with 5–6 hooded hooks per fascicle; females with chaetigers 8–9 having 5–6 hooded hooks and males with chaetigers 8–9 having notopodial spines and neuropodial hooks (
Figs 7
A–D, 8 A, B). Thoracic segments not distinctly biannulate, wider than long; constriction present after chaetiger 4 and 7 and chaetigers 5–7 enlarged in comparison to adjacent thoracic segments (
Figs 7
A, B, 8 A, B). Genital spines present on chaetigers 8–9 of males; chaetiger 8 with two sets of 1–2 spines each facing posteriorly and chaetiger 9 with 2 enlarged spines facing anteriorly (
Figs 7
B, 8 B).

Abdominal segments multi–annulated, almost as long as wide, with hooded hooks throughout. Abdominal hooks similar to thoracics; anteriorly with 5–6 hooded hooks, reduced posteriorly to 2–3 hooks (
Fig. 8
F). Noto- and neuropodia well separated, glandular tori pads poorly developed. Lateral organs and genital pores not observed. Hooded hooks with slightly inflated nodes, main fang extending slightly beyond hoods. Hooks with moderate anterior shaft and two rows of teeth—three in basal row and 2–3 in superior row.

Pygidium an oval lobe with terminal anus (
Figs 7
E, 8 E).

Methyl green staining pattern. Males and females with similar staining pattern. Entire body stains with a solid light green. Prostomium, peristomium and first four chaetigers with sparse green speckles. Chaetigers 5–7 with green speckles concentrated on posterior edge of each segment (
Fig. 6
B); chaetigers 8–9 and sometimes anterior 2–3 abdominal segments with green speckles (
Fig. 6
B); females with larger abdominal stained area than males. Mid- to posterior abdomen lacking distinct MGSP , some specimens with green speckles on the posterior edge of segments.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 7.
Capitella minima :
A, male individual in lateral view; B, male individual in dorsal view showing genital hooks; C, female individual in lateral view; D, female individual in dorsal view; E, posterior end with pygidium.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Distribution.
Capitella minima
is widely distributed in the Atlantic, Mediterranean Sea, Indian Ocean, and Andaman Sea (
Green 2002
). The record in Hawaii of a
Capitella
species with four thoracic chaetigers with capillaries only is new to the western Pacific Ocean.

Remarks. The specimens described herein fit well the description of
Capitella minima
by
Green ( 2002 )
. Several
Capitella
species have capillary chaetae restricted to chaetigers 1–4 :
Capitella minima
,
Capitella minima tulearensis (
Thomassin, 1970
)
,
Capitella capitata floridana
Hartman, 1959
and
Capitella hermaphrodita Boletzky & Dohle, 1967
. However,
C. minima
is distinct from these similar species in having normal capillaries in chaetiger 1 (not an acicular-type as in
C. m. tulearensis
), separate sexes with only males having genital spines, genital spines few in number, peristomium forming a complete ring, distinct MGSP and occurrence in soft sediments rather than restricted to squid egg masses.
Biology. Specimens with fecal pellets adhered to external body wall; no tube observed. Eggs 30–35 µm in diameter.
